choices.text: Tactile stimulation should be repeated for 30 more seconds
Chest compressions should be started immediately
Positive pressure ventilation should be started using a bag-mask device
Epinephrine should be given via the umbilical vein

questions.text: A full-term neonate fails to initiate spontaneous breathing after birth. On examination, the baby is apneic, but the heart rate is 110 bpm. Initial tactile stimulation was already given but was ineffective. Which of the following statements is CORRECT regarding the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In a neonate who is apneic with HR >100 bpm, positive pressure ventilation (PPV) via bag-mask is the next step after ineffective tactile stimulation.

  • In neonatal resuscitation:
    • Apnea with HR >100 bpm indicates the baby is in primary apnea.
    • After ineffective initial steps (drying, positioning, tactile stimulation), positive pressure ventilation (PPV) must be started even if the heart rate is >100.
    • PPV helps inflate the lungs, establish functional residual capacity, and stimulate spontaneous breathing.
    • This is in contrast to secondary apnea, where HR <100 and further interventions like chest compressions may be needed.
    • SpO2 targets in the first 10 minutes after birth:
      • At 1 min: ~60–65%
      • At 5 min: ~80–85%
      • At 10 min: ~85–95% These vary slightly between term and preterm babies, but PPV is started based on HR and breathing effort, not SpO2.

Explanation of other options:

Tactile stimulation should be repeated for 30 more seconds (Option A): Once ineffective, repeated stimulation is not recommended. Proceed to PPV.

Chest compressions should be started immediately (Option B): Chest compressions are only initiated if HR <60 bpm after effective PPV for 30 seconds.

Epinephrine should be given via umbilical vein (Option D): Epinephrine is indicated only when HR remains <60 bpm despite effective PPV and chest compressions.

choices.text: ENBS includes both neuromuscular and physical maturity criteria
ENBS applies to neonates from 20 to 44 weeks of gestation
ENBS can be used to predict the risk of cerebral palsy
ENBS provides an estimated gestational age accurate to ±1 week

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the Expanded New Ballard Score (ENBS) is INCORRECT?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

ENBS is a maturity scoring tool to assess gestational age and does not predict neurological outcomes such as cerebral palsy.

  • The Expanded New Ballard Score (ENBS) is a clinical tool used to assess gestational age in neonates, especially when obstetric dating is uncertain.
  • It evaluates neuromuscular and physical characteristics of the neonate and is commonly used in the first 48–72 hours after birth.
  • Neuromuscular criteria include posture, square window (wrist flexibility), arm recoil, popliteal angle, scarf sign, and heel-to-ear maneuver.
  • Physical criteria include skin texture, breast development, ear/eye development, lanugo, plantar creases, and genitalia.
  • Each criterion is assigned a score, and the total score is matched to a gestational age in weeks, with the ENBS covering neonates from 20 to 44 weeks of gestation.
  • The accuracy of the score is generally within ±1 week when performed properly.
  • Importantly, ENBS is not a predictive tool for neurodevelopmental disorders like cerebral palsy.
  • It is purely an estimation tool for maturity.
  • The ENBS combines physical and neuromuscular signs to assess gestational age.
  • The ENBS was developed to extend the original Ballard Score down to 20 weeks of gestation.
  • When done within 48 hours of birth, the score correlates well with actual gestational age.

questions.text: You are planning to discharge a neonate & explain danger signs to the parents, counseling them to bring the child to the hospital if the baby develops any of these signs. The danger signs will include all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Neonates can normally pass 6-8 stools in 24 hr, and so passing >4 stools in 24 hr is not considered a danger sign.

  • Danger Signs Include:
    • Temperature <35.5° C or >37.5° C (Option A ruled out)
    • Fast breathing with a RR ≥ 60/min
    • Severe Chest indrawing (Option B ruled out)
    • Poor feeding
    • Convulsions
    • Lethargy- Movement only when the baby is stimulated (Option D ruled out)
    • Yellow palms and soles indicate severe hyperbilirubinemia

questions.text: A neonate weighing 1500 grams is delivered at 33 weeks. Which of the following would be the most appropriate method of nutrition for the baby?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nutritional management of a preterm infant aims to achieve full enteral feeding as soon as possible.

  • Feeding of LBW & preterm meconates depends on Gestational Age
    • <28 Week →IV fluids / TPN (Options A, C, D ruled out)
    • 28 - 31 weeks →Tube feeds (Nasogastric/or gastric)
    • 32 - 34 weeks →Spoon feeds/Katori/ Paladai feeds
    • >34 week → Breast feeds
  • TPN is given to VLBW infants who cannot tolerate gastric tube feeds, have gastric disease, enteral feeding (by tube)is not possible, or just while enteral nutrition is being established.
  • Other important indications for TPN are sick premature/LBW infants, which include Infants with:
    • Significant respiratory distress required assisted ventilation.
    • Shock requiring inotropic support.
    • Seizures, renal/cardiac failure

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 2-day-old infant girl is noted to have multiple erythematous papules with small inflammatory pustules on the torso and extremities, but sparing the palms and soles. A smear of the pustule contents is prepared. What would you expect to see on the smear?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Erythema toxicum neonatorum classically shows eosinophils on Wright or Giemsa stains of pustule contents.

  • The infant described has a classical presentation of Erythema Toxicum Neonatorum (ETN)-a common, benign, self-limiting rash seen in term neonates.
  • It typically appears within 24 to 72 hours after birth and is characterized by:
    • Multiple erythematous macules, papules, and pustules
    • Distribution over face, trunk, and proximal limbs
    • Sparing of palms and soles, which helps differentiate it from other neonatal pustular disorders
    • Infants are otherwise well and afebrile
  • The key diagnostic clue is the cytology of the pustule content.
  • A Wright or Giemsa stain reveals numerous eosinophils, which are diagnostic of ETN.
  • The rash resolves spontaneously within 5–7 days without treatment.

Explanation of other options:

Langerhans cells (Option A): Seen in Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis, a pathological condition with persistent skin lesions and systemic involvement-not seen in ETN.

Neutrophils (Option B): Predominant in Transient Neonatal Pustular Melanosis, which presents at birth and shows pigmented macules after pustules rupture.

Gram-positive cocci (Option C): Suggestive of bacterial infections like staphylococcal pustulosis, which is typically associated with systemic symptoms or ill appearance.

questions.text: A neonate with respiratory distress is being monitored using the Silverman Anderson scoring method. The child has a respiratory rate of 60/min, there is no cyanosis on 30% oxygen, some lag in inspiration on the upper chest, there are minimal retractions in the lower chest that are just visible, there are no xiphoid retractions or nasal flaring, and intermittent grunting can be heard with a stethoscope. What is the total score?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Silverman Anderson Score in this neonate adds up to 3 based on mild respiratory distress signs.

  • The Silverman Anderson Scoring system is a clinical tool used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in neonates.
  • It consists of 5 parameters, each scored as 0 (normal), 1 (moderate), or 2 (severe).
  • The total score ranges from 0 (no distress) to 10 (severe distress).
  • Let's calculate the score based on this baby’s findings:
    • Upper chest movement: Some lag in inspiration: 1
    • Lower chest retraction: Minimal (just visible): 1
    • Xiphoid retraction: None : 0
    • Nasal flaring None : 0
    • Expiratory grunt: Intermittent, heard only with stethoscope: 1
    • Total Score = 1 + 1 + 0 + 0 + 1 = 3
  • A score of 3 indicates mild to moderate respiratory distress.
  • This scoring system helps in objectifying distress and monitoring progress, especially in preterm infants.

Reference: 

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4922755/

questions.text: Vitamin K is given at birth to prevent the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vitamin K is given at birth to prevent hemorrhagic disease of the newborn, a bleeding disorder due to vitamin K–K-dependent clotting factor deficiency.

  • Vitamin K deficiency bleeding (VKDB), formerly called hemorrhagic disease of the newborn, is a potentially fatal condition resulting from low levels of vitamin K–K-dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, and X) in neonates.
  • This deficiency is physiological, due to:
    • Poor placental transfer of vitamin K
    • Lack of gut flora at birth (needed for endogenous vitamin K production)
    • Low vitamin K content in breast milk
  • To prevent VKDB, vitamin K1 (phytonadione) is routinely administered intramuscularly (IM) soon after birth.
  • Recommended dose:
    • Term neonates: 1 mg IM
    • Preterm neonates <1.5 kg: 0.5 mg IM
  • Forms available: Vitamin K1 (phytonadione), injectable form. Oral preparations exist but are less effective in preventing late VKDB.
  • VKDB types:
    • Early VKDB: within 24 hrs; seen in infants of mothers on anticonvulsants or anti-TB drugs.
    • Classic VKDB: day 2–7; most common.
    • Late VKDB: week 2 to 12; exclusively breastfed infants not given vitamin K.
  • Routine IM administration of vitamin K1 at birth virtually eliminates all forms of VKDB.

Explanation of other options:

Neonatal asphyxia (Option B): Caused by perinatal hypoxia; unrelated to vitamin K deficiency or clotting factor synthesis.

Neonatal hypoglycemia (Option C): Typically associated with maternal diabetes or IUGR; not prevented by vitamin K.

Hemolytic anemia (Option D): Caused by blood group incompatibilities or enzyme deficiencies like G6PD; unrelated to vitamin K.

choices.text: Needle suction may be needed if size >2 cm

questions.text: A child was delivered by normal vaginal delivery, and immediately after delivery, it was noticed that the child had swelling on his scalp. The swelling was soft, mainly present in the frontal area with some extension to the adjacent parietal area, and an X-ray was done as shown below. What is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The swelling is most consistent with caput succedaneum, which is self-limiting and requires only observation.

  • The key features here—soft swelling of the scalp that is present at birth, involves frontal and parietal areas, and crosses suture lines—are classical for caput succedaneum.
  • This condition results from pressure during vaginal delivery, causing edema in the subcutaneous tissue of the scalp.
  • Caput succedaneum:
    • Present at birth
    • Crosses suture lines
    • Located in subcutaneous tissue
    • Feels soft and boggy
    • Resolves spontaneously within a few days (usually 2–4 days)
    • No treatment is needed
  • In contrast, cephalohematoma is:
    • Located beneath the periosteum
    • Does not cross suture lines
    • Appears hours after birth
    • May persist for weeks
    • May require monitoring for jaundice or calcification
  • Hence, the correct management of caput succedaneum is observation alone.

Explanation of other options:

Cephalohematoma is a likely possibility (Option A): Cephalohematoma is confined by suture lines and appears hours after birth, unlike the soft, diffuse swelling seen here.

May persist for 3–6 weeks (Option C): This duration applies to cephalohematoma, not caput succedaneum, which resolves within days.

Needle suction may be needed if size >2 cm (Option D): Needle aspiration is contraindicated in caput succedaneum due to risk of infection and is not recommended even in cephalohematoma.

questions.text: Which among the following is the earliest to appear in a child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ulnar palmar grasp reflex is the earliest primitive reflex to appear, typically observed from 28 weeks of gestation.

  • Primitive reflexes are automatic movements seen in infants, originating from the brainstem, and serve important developmental functions.
  • They appear at specific gestational ages and gradually disappear as higher cortical centers mature.
  • The ulnar palmar grasp reflex is the earliest to appear among those listed, detectable as early as 28 weeks of gestation, and becomes fully developed by 32–36 weeks.
  • It is elicited by placing a finger in the infant's palm, leading to involuntary grasping.

Explanation of other options:

Moro's Reflex (Option A): Appears by 28–32 weeks of gestation but is slightly later than the palmar grasp reflex in onset.

Asymmetric tonic neck reflex (Option B): Appears around 35 weeks of gestation, hence later than the grasp and Moro reflexes.

Parachute Reflex (Option C): This is a postnatal reflex, appearing around 6–9 months of age, and is used to assess motor development and cerebral palsy in older infants.

Table: Neonatal Reflexes

questions.text: During the 1-week health supervision visit, a mother who is exclusively breastfeeding asks about vitamin and iron supplementation for her healthy term infant. She explains that her previous child, who was born at 30 weeks of gestation, was discharged with an oral iron supplement and vitamins. The baby has already received 1 intramuscular shot of Vitamin K at birth. Of the following, the MOST appropriate oral supplement to initiate for this infant at this visit is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Exclusively breastfed term infants should receive 400 IU/day of vitamin D starting within the first few days of life.

  • According to AAP (American Academy of Pediatrics), all exclusively or partially breastfed infants should be given a daily supplement of 400 IU of oral vitamin D, beginning in the first few days after birth.
  • Breast milk is typically low in vitamin D, and supplementation helps prevent nutritional rickets.
  • This is distinct from the vitamin K prophylaxis given as a single intramuscular dose at birth (usually 0.5–1 mg IM), which is done to prevent hemorrhagic disease of the newborn.
  • This dose does not eliminate the need for ongoing vitamin D supplementation in breastfed infants.
  • Iron supplementation, in contrast, is generally initiated at 4 months of age in exclusively breastfed term infants.
  • Preterm infants (like her previous 30-week child) have lower iron stores and require earlier supplementation, hence the confusion.

Explanation of other options:

Calcium (Option A): Not routinely required in healthy term infants unless there's a metabolic disorder or specific risk factor.

Folic acid (Option B): Not needed in term neonates unless there's a specific deficiency or underlying condition.

Iron (Option C): Iron supplementation in term infants begins at 4 months if exclusively breastfed; starting at 1 week is unnecessary.

questions.text: A 38-week neonate developed poor feeding, lethargy, and bradycardia. Since the thermometer was unavailable, you palpated the skin of the baby using the dorsum of your own hands. You found that the central body is warm to the touch, but the peripheries are cold & slightly cyanotic. Likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cold stress is indicated when the core is warm but the peripheries are cold, signaling the early phase of neonatal hypothermia.

  • Cold stress is the initial phase of neonatal hypothermia, where peripheral vasoconstriction occurs to preserve core body temperature.
  • In this phase, the trunk remains warm, while the extremities are cold and may appear cyanotic.
  • The baby may present with lethargy, poor feeding, bradycardia, and hypoglycemia.
  • Since thermoregulation is underdeveloped in neonates, especially in cold environments, skin-to-skin contact, warm ambient temperature, and appropriate clothing are key preventive measures.
  • Recognition of cold stress is clinical in settings where thermometers are not immediately available—palpation using the dorsum of the hand is a practical method.
  • If not corrected early, cold stress can progress to moderate or severe hypothermia, which may cause metabolic acidosis, apnea, and even death.

Explanation of other options:

Raynaud's Phenomenon (Option A): This is a vasospastic disorder affecting older children or adults, usually triggered by cold or stress, not seen in neonates.

Harlequin colour change (Option B): A benign and transient condition in newborns where one half of the body turns red and the other pale, not associated with lethargy or bradycardia.

Severe hypothermia (Option D): In severe hypothermia, both the core and peripheries are cold, and the neonate is often unresponsive. In this case, the trunk was warm, ruling out severe hypothermia.

questions.text: You are an intern reading the birth card of an infant. You find that the report mentions an APGAR Score of 3 at 1 minute. This indicates what type of APGAR Score?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An APGAR score of 0–3 at 1 minute signifies severe neonatal depression requiring immediate resuscitation.

  • The APGAR score is a quick assessment done at 1 and 5 minutes after birth to evaluate a newborn's physical condition and need for immediate medical intervention.
  • It assesses five parameters: Appearance (color), Pulse, Grimace (reflex), Activity (muscle tone), and Respiration — each scored from 0 to 2, with a total maximum score of 10.
    • Score 7–10: Normal
    • Score 4–6: Moderately depressed
    • Score 0–3: Severely depressed
  • A score of 3 at 1 minute indicates severe perinatal depression, possibly due to birth asphyxia, and demands immediate and aggressive resuscitation.
  • Subsequent scores at 5 and 10 minutes guide prognosis and ongoing intervention.

questions.text: What is the cut-off to define apnea in a neonate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Apnea in a neonate is defined as a pause in breathing lasting ≥20 seconds, or a shorter pause associated with bradycardia, cyanosis, or hypotonia.

  • Apnea in neonates is a common clinical condition, especially in preterm infants, due to immature central respiratory control.
  • The standard cut-off to define apnea is a pause in breathing that lasts ≥20 seconds.
  • However, even shorter pauses (<20 seconds) are clinically significant if they are associated with:
    • Bradycardia
    • Desaturation (cyanosis)
    • Hypotonia
  • Types of neonatal apnea:
    • Central apnea – absence of respiratory effort
    • Obstructive apnea – respiratory effort present, but airflow absent
    • Mixed apnea – features of both
  • This definition helps in diagnosing apnea of prematurity and distinguishing it from other causes of respiratory distress.

Explanation of other options:

10 sec (Option A): Normal neonates may have periodic breathing with short pauses <20 seconds, which is not defined as apnea.

15 sec (Option B): Still below the diagnostic threshold unless accompanied by bradycardia or cyanosis.

30 sec (Option D): This is an excessively long pause and represents severe apnea, but the diagnostic cut-off is ≥20 seconds.

questions.text: A term neonate is sick and cannot be immediately started on mother's milk. He has started on IV Fluids. What shall be the total amount to be given on day 1 to this baby?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

On day 1 of life, a term neonate who is not feeding should receive 60 ml/kg/day of IV fluids.

  • Neonatal fluid management is based on day of life, gestational age, and clinical condition.
  • In full-term neonates who are unable to tolerate enteral feeds, IV fluid therapy is initiated with calculated maintenance volumes.
  • For term neonates:
    • Day 1: 60 ml/kg/day
    • Day 2: 75–90 ml/kg/day
    • Day 3: 90–100 ml/kg/day
    • And gradually increasing to 150 ml/kg/day by day 7.
  • This fluid includes glucose-containing solutions (typically 10% dextrose) and should be adjusted based on:
    • Urine output
    • Clinical status
    • Serum electrolytes
  • Too much fluid in the early neonatal period can lead to complications like patent ductus arteriosus, bronchopulmonary dysplasia, or fluid overload, hence the cautious approach.

Explanation of other options:

70 ml/kg (Option B): This is more appropriate for day 2 in a stable neonate, not for day 1.

80 ml/kg (Option C): Slightly excessive for day 1 and not recommended as the starting volume.

90 ml/kg (Option D): This is usually targeted on day 3, depending on urine output and weight changes.

questions.text: A neonate has not passed urine in the last 24 hours since birth. The next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

It is normal for term neonates to pass urine within the first 24–48 hours of life; observation and continued breastfeeding are the appropriate initial steps.

  • Most healthy term neonates pass urine within the first 24 hours of life, but delayed urination up to 48 hours can still be within normal limits, especially if the baby is otherwise feeding well and shows no signs of dehydration or sepsis.
  • The kidneys of neonates are immature, and during the early hours after birth, urine output may be low.
  • If the baby is active, feeding adequately, and has no signs of systemic illness (like lethargy, abdominal distension, or vomiting), observation and continued breastfeeding are appropriate.
  • Close monitoring is required, and if no urine is passed by 48 hours or if the baby shows any abnormal signs, further workup is needed.

Explanation of other options:

Admit to NICU (Option B): This is not necessary unless the baby is clinically unwell or does not pass urine by 48 hours with other concerning signs.

Start formula feeds (Option C): There's no indication to stop breastfeeding or start formula unless the baby is not gaining weight or has feeding issues.

Start IV fluids (Option D): Not needed unless there is evidence of dehydration or critical illness; this is an overstep in an otherwise stable neonate.

questions.text: Expressed breast milk can be stored at room temperature for how much time?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

At room temperature (up to 25°C), expressed breast milk is safe for 6–8 hours if collected hygienically.

  • Expressed breast milk (EBM) provides optimal nutrition and immunity for infants when direct breastfeeding is not feasible.
  • The safe duration for storing EBM at room temperature depends on ambient temperature and hygiene during expression.
  • At room temperature (<25°C), EBM remains safe for 6–8 hours.
  • If ambient temperature is higher (e.g., >30°C), safe storage time reduces to <4 hours.
  • In refrigerator (4°C): up to 48–72 hours
  • In freezer (−18°C): up to 3–6 months
  • Proper collection using sterilized containers and avoiding repeated warming are crucial.
  • Breast milk has antibacterial properties, but microbial growth increases with time and temperature.

choices.text: Breast milk contains more Vitamin K

questions.text: Which of the following is correct when comparing breast milk with cow's milk?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The absolute amount of calcium is less in breast milk than in animal milk, but since the Calcium  Phosphorus Ratio is 2:1, the absorption is better.

  • Key points to note:
    • Vitamins deficientin breast milk: Vit K, Vit D, Vit B1
    • Mineral deficientin breast milk: Fluoride
    • Breast milkhas more lactose but less fat, protein, and calcium than animal milk
    • Breast milk is richin Whey protein (better) compared to casein of animal milk. Breast milk also has more Taurine and Cysteine
    • Breast milk has more MUFA, PUFA, and is especially rich in DHA, i.e., Docosahexaenoic Acid

questions.text: Breastfeeding should be started within how much time after birth?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Breastfeeding should be initiated within the first hour of birth to enhance bonding and reduce neonatal mortality.

  • The World Health Organization (WHO), UNICEF, and the Indian Academy of Pediatrics (IAP) recommend initiating breastfeeding within 1 hour of birth, regardless of the mode of delivery (vaginal or cesarean, if feasible).
  • Early initiation of breastfeeding:
    • Promotes early skin-to-skin contact, helping with thermoregulation.
    • Enhances mother-infant bonding.
    • Ensures early feeding with colostrum, which is rich in IgA and immune cells.
    • Significantly reduces neonatal mortality, especially from infections.
    • Stimulates uterine contractions, aiding in the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage in the mother.
  • Delayed initiation (after 1 hour) is associated with increased risk of neonatal infections and suboptimal breastfeeding practices.

choices.text: Intrapartum suctioning of mouth and oropharynx
Tracheal suction in all vigorous MSL babies
Positive-pressure ventilation in all non-vigorous MSL babies
Gentle suction of mouth and nose in vigorous MSL babies

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding management and resuscitation in a baby born through meconium-stained liquor (MSL)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Non-vigorous babies born through MSL require immediate PPV, not routine tracheal suctioning, as per NRP guidelines.

  • In the Neonatal Resuscitation Program (NRP) 2020 and later, the management of MSL depends on the baby's clinical status, not the presence of meconium alone:
    • Vigorous baby (HR >100, strong cry, good tone): Do not intubate or suction the trachea. Gentle suctioning of mouth/nose only if needed.
    • Non-vigorous baby (HR <100, poor tone, absent/weak cry): Immediate positive pressure ventilation (PPV) is the priority.
  • Routine tracheal suctioning for non-vigorous babies is no longer recommended, as studies show it delays ventilation without improving outcomes.

Explanation of other options:

Intrapartum suctioning of mouth and oropharynx (Option A): Obsolete practice; no longer recommended in current NRP guidelines.

Tracheal suction in all vigorous MSL babies (Option B): Vigorous babies do not require tracheal suction even in the presence of MSL.

Gentle suction of mouth and nose in vigorous MSL babies (Option D): This is true for vigorous babies, but not applicable here since the baby is non-vigorous-hence, not the correct answer for this scenario.

questions.text: A term baby is born after an uncomplicated pregnancy to a 33-year-old mother. At birth, he was lethargic and had an HR of 40. Oxygen was administered via bag and mask, and he was intubated; his HR remained at 40 beats/min despite adequate PPV. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chest compressions are indicated when the heart rate remains <60/min after 30 seconds of effective PPV with 100% oxygen.

  • According to the Neonatal Resuscitation Program (NRP) 8th edition, if a newborn has a heart rate <60 beats per minute despite 30 seconds of effective PPV with chest movement, the next immediate step is to initiate chest compressions coordinated with ventilation.
  • In this case, the baby received bag-mask ventilation and was intubated, yet the heart rate remains at 40 bpm — indicating inadequate perfusion.
  • Since PPV was adequate (air entry ensured by intubation), persistent bradycardia (<60 bpm) suggests the need to escalate resuscitation by starting chest compressions, which helps restore effective circulation.
  • Chest compressions in neonates should be given at a ratio of 3:1 (compressions: breaths), aiming for 90 compressions and 30 breaths per minute (120 events/min).
  • Compressions are done using the two-thumb encircling hands technique on the lower third of the sternum.

Explanation of other options:

Administer IV bicarbonate (Option A): Bicarbonate is not first-line in neonatal resuscitation. It may be used later in prolonged resuscitation or metabolic acidosis, but not before compressions are attempted.

Stimulate the baby again (Option B): Tactile stimulation is indicated only in the initial assessment for apnea or poor tone. This baby has already received PPV and is intubated, so stimulation is inappropriate here.

Tracheal suctioning (Option C): Indicated only if there is meconium-stained amniotic fluid and the baby is non-vigorous. In this case, there is no mention of meconium or obstruction.

choices.text: Suctioning of the nose should always be done before the mouth
Suctioning of the mouth should precede suctioning of the nose
Routine tracheal suctioning is recommended for all neonates
Tracheal suctioning should always be done before clearing the oral and nasal passages

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding suctioning during neonatal resuscitation is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The mouth should be suctioned before the nose to avoid aspiration from gasping.

  • During neonatal resuscitation, if the newborn has secretions that obstruct spontaneous breathing or is not vigorous, suctioning is done as part of the initial stabilization steps.
  • The correct sequence is to suction the mouth first, followed by the nose.
  • This prevents aspiration of oropharyngeal contents if the baby gasps during nasal suctioning.
  • Routine tracheal suctioning is not indicated unless there's evidence of meconium-stained amniotic fluid with a non-vigorous baby and other complications requiring advanced airway management.

Explanation of other options:

Suctioning of the nose should always be done before the mouth (Option A): Incorrect, as suctioning the nose first can stimulate inspiration and cause aspiration of oral secretions.

Routine tracheal suctioning is recommended for all neonates (Option C): Not true. Tracheal suctioning is reserved for specific situations like non-vigorous babies with meconium-stained liquor.

Tracheal suctioning should always be done before clearing the oral and nasal passages (Option D): This sequence is incorrect and not part of routine neonatal resuscitation steps.

choices.text: Wait for shock to spontaneously improve

questions.text: A neonate was resuscitated successfully but was found to develop hypovolemic shock. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In neonatal hypovolemic shock, a normal saline bolus (10 mL/kg) is the fluid of choice for initial volume resuscitation.

  • If a neonate shows signs of hypovolemic shock after successful resuscitation, the first-line treatment is volume expansion using isotonic fluid, preferably 0.9% Normal Saline.
  • The recommended dose is 10 mL/kg administered over 5–10 minutes, and the infant should be closely monitored for response.
  • This is crucial because persistent hypoperfusion may lead to end-organ injury.
  • Delaying intervention in neonatal shock is dangerous and can worsen outcomes. Immediate management is critical. (Option A ruled out)
  • Epinephrine is considered after a fluid bolus if shock persists or if it is cardiogenic in nature. (Option B ruled out)
  • Epinephrine is used in refractory shock or when bradycardia persists despite ventilation and fluid resuscitation.
  • It is not the first step in hypovolemic shock.
  • Ringer's Lactate is not routinely preferred in neonates due to concerns about liver immaturity affecting lactate metabolism. (Option D ruled out)
  • Although it's also an isotonic fluid, Normal Saline is preferred in neonates due to a more predictable electrolyte composition and avoidance of lactate.

choices.text: Give a bolus dose of Caffeine

questions.text: A preterm neonate, admitted to the hospital & receiving Caffeine Citrate, becomes suddenly apneic and unresponsive. What is the immediate next step to take?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bag and Mask Ventilation (BMV) is the immediate life-saving step in a neonate who is apneic and unresponsive, regardless of ongoing methylxanthine therapy.

  • Apnea of prematurity (AOP) is common in preterm neonates due to immature central respiratory control.
  • Caffeine citrate is the drug of choice used prophylactically or therapeutically in these cases.
  • However, if a neonate who is already on caffeine suddenly becomes apneic and unresponsive, it is a medical emergency requiring immediate resuscitative measures.
  • The first step is to ensure airway, breathing, and circulation.
  • This means starting bag and mask ventilation (BMV) immediately to restore breathing and oxygenation.
  • Further interventions like adjusting caffeine dosing or considering alternate drugs like theophylline can only be done after stabilizing the airway and circulation.

Explanation of other options:

Wait and watch (Option A): Delaying intervention in an unresponsive and apneic neonate can be fatal; immediate action is necessary.

Give a bolus dose of Caffeine (Option C): Caffeine has a delayed onset of action and is not effective for immediate resuscitation.

Add Theophylline (Option D): Theophylline is another methylxanthine used for AOP but is not useful acutely and not preferred over caffeine due to higher side effects.
